text: So a couple of other things that I wanted to look at will, I know you have often looked at on chain indicators for your analysis, and there's one in particular that I was curious about, which is the realized price, which basically is where you take every coin, you multiply it by the price of its last movement, and then you divide the value of that by the circulating supply. And you have said that you feel this is one of the biggest drivers of bitcoins price dynamics. So what are you seeing now in terms of realized price and how that might affect bitcoin in the short to medium term?

speaker: A
text: Yeah, I used to track a lot of the on chain analytics stuff, like pretty closely. What I found is just not that actionable for trading, at least on short to medium term timeframes. What I do think its decent for is getting a proxy of the valuation of bitcoin. Theres not a lot of great ways to value bitcoin. Some people like to look at the energy price. This MVRV thing is one of my favorite valuation methodologies that people have come up with for bitcoin. So basically compares the realized value to the market value as you just described. Realized value is basically looks at the price that every coin was last moved. It essentially gives you an aggregated cost basis of the network. Then the idea of comparing that to what the current marginal trading price is, basically, where is the market trading relative to the cost basis of the network? What weve seen historically is whenever this ratio gets up to a ratio of about six to seven, the markets topped out. Whenever it goes negative, it means that the market is underwater in aggregate. So thats when you want to be buying. Its more of an art than a science, but its something that I look at as okay. On this spectrum evaluation based on where bitcoin has historically topped out, you can get somewhat of a rough proxy as to how it's trading and where maybe it sits and its cyclical dynamics. Right now, we're just sitting midway in between both of those bounds. I don't really think there's anything super actionable to derive from that. We're still not in that undervalued territory, but we're still not in that super overheated territory that was reached at the end of 2017 or the end of 2021.
